The **1990 FIFA World Cup** was the 14th [FIFA World Cup](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup
"FIFA World Cup"), the [quadrennial](/wiki/Anniversary#Latin-
derived_numerical_names "Anniversary") international
[football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football") tournament. It
was held from 8 June to 8 July 1990 in Italy, the second country to host the
event twice (the first being Mexico in [1986](/wiki/1986_FIFA_World_Cup "1986
FIFA World Cup")). Teams representing 116 national football associations
entered and [qualification](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification "1990 FIFA
World Cup qualification") began in April 1988. 22 teams qualified from this
process, along with host nation [Italy](/wiki/Italy_national_football_team
"Italy national football team") and defending champions
[Argentina](/wiki/Argentina_national_football_team "Argentina national
football team").

The tournament was won by [West Germany](/wiki/Germany_national_football_team
"Germany national football team"), their third World Cup title. They [beat
Argentina 1–0](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_Final "1990 FIFA World Cup Final") at
the [Stadio Olimpico](/wiki/Stadio_Olimpico "Stadio Olimpico") in
[Rome](/wiki/Rome "Rome"), a rematch of [the previous
final](/wiki/1986_FIFA_World_Cup_Final "1986 FIFA World Cup Final") four years
earlier. Italy finished third and
[England](/wiki/England_national_football_team "England national football
team") fourth, after both lost their semi-finals in [penalty
shootouts](/wiki/Penalty_shoot-out_\(association_football\) "Penalty shoot-out
\(association football\)"). This was the last tournament to feature a team
from West Germany, with the country being [reunified with East
Germany](/wiki/German_reunification "German reunification") a few months later
in October, as well as teams from the [Eastern Bloc](/wiki/Eastern_Bloc
"Eastern Bloc") prior to the end of the [Cold War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War")
in 1991, as the [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_national_football_team "Soviet
national football team"), [Romania](/wiki/Romania_national_football_team
"Romania national football team"),
[Czechoslovakia](/wiki/Czechoslovakia_national_football_team "Czechoslovakia
national football team") and
[Yugoslavia](/wiki/Yugoslavia_national_football_team "Yugoslavia national
football team") teams made appearances. [Costa
Rica](/wiki/Costa_Rica_national_football_team "Costa Rica national football
team"), [Ireland](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland_national_football_team "Republic
of Ireland national football team") and [the
UAE](/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates_national_football_team "United Arab Emirates
national football team") made their first appearances in the finals. As of
2018, this was the last time the UAE qualified for a FIFA World Cup finals.
The official match ball was the [Adidas Etrusco
Unico](/wiki/Adidas_Etrusco_Unico "Adidas Etrusco Unico").

The 1990 World Cup is widely regarded as one of the poorest World Cups in
terms of the games.[1][2][3][4] It generated an average 2.2 goals per game – a
record low that still stands[5] – and a then-record 16 red cards, including
the first ever dismissal in a final. Regarded as being the World Cup that has
had perhaps the most lasting influence on the game as a whole,[6] it saw the
introduction of the pre-match Fair Play Flag (then inscribed with "Fair Play
Please") to encourage fair play. Defensive tactics led to the introduction of
the [back-pass rule](/wiki/Back-pass_rule "Back-pass rule") in 1992 and [three
points for a win](/wiki/Three_points_for_a_win "Three points for a win")
instead of two at future World Cups. The tournament also produced some of the
World Cup’s best remembered moments and stories, including the emergence of
African nations, in addition to what has become the World Cup soundtrack:
“[Nessun dorma](/wiki/Nessun_dorma "Nessun dorma")”.[6]

The 1990 World Cup stands as one of the most watched events in television
history, garnering an estimated 26.69 billion non-unique viewers over the
course of the tournament.[7] This was the first World Cup to be officially
recorded and transmitted in [HDTV](/wiki/HDTV "HDTV") by the Italian
broadcaster [RAI](/wiki/RAI "RAI") in association with Japan's [NHK](/wiki/NHK
"NHK").[8] The huge success of the broadcasting model has also had a lasting
impact on the sport.[6] At the time it was the most watched World Cup in
history in non-unique viewers, but was bettered by the
[1994](/wiki/1994_FIFA_World_Cup "1994 FIFA World Cup") and [2002 World
Cups](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup "2002 FIFA World Cup").[9]

## Host
selection[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1990_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Host selection")]

Main article: [FIFA World Cup hosts](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_hosts "FIFA World
Cup hosts")

The vote to choose the hosts of the 1990 tournament was held on 19 May 1984 in
[Zürich](/wiki/Z%C3%BCrich "Zürich"), Switzerland. Here, the FIFA Executive
Committee chose Italy ahead of the only rival bid, the
[USSR](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union"), by 11 votes to 5.[10] This awarding
made Italy only the second nation to host two World Cup tournaments, after
Mexico had also achieved this with their [1986
staging](/wiki/1986_FIFA_World_Cup "1986 FIFA World Cup"). Italy had
previously had the event in [1934](/wiki/1934_FIFA_World_Cup "1934 FIFA World
Cup"), where they had won their first championship.

Austria, England, France, Greece, West Germany and Yugoslavia also submitted
initial applications for 31 July 1983 deadline.[11] A month later, only
England, Greece, Italy and the Soviet Union remained in the hunt after the
other contenders all withdrew.[12] All four bids were assessed by FIFA in late
1983, with the final decision over-running into 1984 due to the volume of
paperwork involved.[13] In early 1984, England and Greece also withdrew,
leading to a two-horse race in the final vote. The [Soviet boycott of the 1984
Olympic Games](/wiki/1984_Summer_Olympics_boycott "1984 Summer Olympics
boycott"), announced on the eve of the World Cup decision, was speculated to
have been a major factor behind Italy winning the vote so decisively,[14]
although this was denied by the FIFA President [João
Havelange](/wiki/Jo%C3%A3o_Havelange "João Havelange").[10]

##
Qualification[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1990_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Qualification")]

Main article: [1990 FIFA World Cup
qualification](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification "1990 FIFA World Cup
qualification")

116 teams entered the 1990 World Cup, including Italy as host nation and
Argentina as reigning World Cup champions, who were both granted automatic
qualification. Thus, the remaining 22 finals places were divided among the
continental confederations, with 114 initially entering the qualification
competition. Due to rejected entries and withdrawals, 103 teams eventually
participated in the qualifying stages.

Thirteen places were contested by [UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA") teams (Europe),
two by [CONMEBOL](/wiki/CONMEBOL "CONMEBOL") teams (South America), two by
[CAF](/wiki/Confederation_of_African_Football "Confederation of African
Football") teams (Africa), two by [AFC](/wiki/Asian_Football_Confederation
"Asian Football Confederation") teams (Asia), and two by
[CONCACAF](/wiki/CONCACAF "CONCACAF") teams (North and Central America and
Caribbean). The remaining place was decided by a play-off between a CONMEBOL
team and a team from the [OFC](/wiki/Oceania_Football_Confederation "Oceania
Football Confederation") (Oceania).

Both [Mexico](/wiki/Mexico_national_football_team "Mexico national football
team") and [Chile](/wiki/Chile_national_football_team "Chile national football
team") were disqualified during the qualification process; the former for
fielding an overage player in a prior youth tournament,[15] the latter after
goalkeeper [Roberto Rojas](/wiki/Roberto_Rojas "Roberto Rojas") faked injury
from a firework thrown from the stands, which caused the match to be
abandoned. Chile were also banned from the [1994
qualifiers](/wiki/1994_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification "1994 FIFA World Cup
qualification") for this offence.

Three teams made their debuts, as this was the first World Cup to feature
[Costa Rica](/wiki/Costa_Rica_national_football_team "Costa Rica national
football team") and the [Republic of
Ireland](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland_national_football_team "Republic of Ireland
national football team"), and the only one to date to feature the [United Arab
Emirates](/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates_national_football_team "United Arab
Emirates national football team").

Returning after long absences were Egypt, who appeared for the first time
since 1934, the [United
States](/wiki/United_States_men%27s_national_soccer_team "United States men's
national soccer team"), who competed for the first time since 1950, Colombia,
who appeared for the first time since 1962, Romania, who last appeared at the
Finals in 1970 and Sweden and the Netherlands, both of which last qualified in
1978. Austria, Cameroon, Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia also returned after
missing the 1986 tournament.

Among the teams who failed to qualify were 1986 semi-finalists France (missing
out their first World Cup since 1974), Denmark, Poland (for the first time
since 1970), Portugal and Hungary.

## Venues[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1990_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Venues")]

Twelve stadiums in twelve cities were selected to host matches at the 1990
World Cup. The [Stadio San Nicola](/wiki/Stadio_San_Nicola "Stadio San
Nicola") in [Bari](/wiki/Bari "Bari") and [Turin](/wiki/Turin "Turin")'s
[Stadio delle Alpi](/wiki/Stadio_delle_Alpi "Stadio delle Alpi") were
completely new venues opened for the World Cup.

The remaining ten venues all underwent extensive programmes of improvements in
preparation for the tournament, forcing many of the club tenants of the stadia
to move to temporary homes. Additional seating and roofs were added to most
stadia, with further redevelopments seeing running tracks removed and new
pitches laid. Due to structural constraints, several of the existing stadia
had to be virtually rebuilt to implement the changes required.

Like Espana '82, the group stage of this tournament was organized in such a
way where specific groups only played in two cities close in proximity to each
other. Group A only played in Rome and Florence (Hosts Italy played all their
competitive matches in Rome, except for their semi-final and third place
matches, which were played in Naples and Bari, respectively), Group B played
their matches in Naples and Bari (except for Argentina vs. Cameroon, which was
the opening match of the tournament, played in Milan), Group C played their
matches in Turin and Genoa, Group D played all their matches in Milan and
Bologna, Group E played only in Udine and Verona, and Group F played on the
island cities of Cagliari and Palermo. The cities that hosted the most World
Cup matches were the two biggest cities in Italy: Rome and Milan, each hosting
six matches, and Bari, Naples and Turin each hosted five matches. Cagliari,
Udine and Palermo were the only cities of the 12 selected that did not host
any knockout round matches.

The England national team, at the British government's request, were forced to
play all their matches in Cagliari on the island of Sardinia. Hooliganism,
[rife in English football in the
1980s](/wiki/Football_hooliganism_in_the_United_Kingdom#1980s "Football
hooliganism in the United Kingdom"), had followed the national team while they
played friendlies on the European continent – the distrust of English fans was
so high that the English FA's reputation and even diplomatic relations between
the UK and Italy were seen to be at risk if England played any group stage
matches on the Italian mainland. Thanks largely to British Sports Minister
Colin Moynihan's negative remarks about English fans weeks before the match,
security around Cagliari during England's three matches there was extremely
heavy – in addition to 7,000 local police and Carabineri, highly trained
Italian military special forces were also there patrolling the premises. The
Italian authorities' heavy presence proved to be justified as there were
several riots during the time England were playing their matches in Cagliari,
leading to a number of injuries, arrests and even deportations.[16][17]

Most of the construction cost in excess of their original estimates and total
costs ended up being over £550 million (approximately $935 million). Rome's
[Stadio Olimpico](/wiki/Stadio_Olimpico "Stadio Olimpico") which would host
the final was the most expensive project overall, while Udine's [Stadio
Friuli](/wiki/Stadio_Friuli "Stadio Friuli"), the newest of the existing
stadia (opened 14 years prior), cost the least to redevelop.

[Milan](/wiki/Milan "Milan") | [Rome](/wiki/Rome "Rome") | [Turin](/wiki/Turin "Turin") | [Naples](/wiki/Naples "Naples")

## Squads[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1990_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Squads")]

Further information: [1990 FIFA World Cup
squads](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_squads "1990 FIFA World Cup squads")

Squads for the 1990 World Cup consisted of 22 players, as for the previous
tournament in 1986. Replacement of injured players was permitted during the
tournament at FIFA's discretion. Two goalkeepers – Argentina's [Ángel
Comizzo](/wiki/%C3%81ngel_Comizzo "Ángel Comizzo") and England's [Dave
Beasant](/wiki/Dave_Beasant "Dave Beasant") – entered their respective squads
during the tournament to replace injured players ([Nery
Pumpido](/wiki/Nery_Pumpido "Nery Pumpido") and [David
Seaman](/wiki/David_Seaman "David Seaman")).

## Match
officials[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1990_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Match officials")]

41 match officials from 34 countries were assigned to the tournament to serve
as referees and assistant referees. Officials in italics were only used as
assistants during the tournament. Referees dressed only in traditional black
jerseys for the final time at a World Cup (a red change shirt was used for two
Group C games in which Scotland wore their navy blue shirts).

## Groups[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1990_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Groups")]

###
Seedings[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1990_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Seedings")]

The six [seeded](/wiki/Seed_\(sports\) "Seed \(sports\)") teams for the 1990
tournament were announced on 7 December 1989.[20] The seeds were then
allocated to the six groups in order of their seeding rank (1st seed to Group
A, 2nd seed to Group B, etc.).

The seeds were decided by FIFA based on the nations' performance in,
primarily, the [1986 World Cup](/wiki/1986_FIFA_World_Cup "1986 FIFA World
Cup") with the [1982 World Cup](/wiki/1982_FIFA_World_Cup "1982 FIFA World
Cup") also considered as a secondary influence. Six of the final eight in 1986
had qualified for the 1990 tournament, the missing nations being Mexico
(quarter-final in 1986) and France (third place). Italy – who were seeded
first as hosts – had not reached the final eight in 1986 and this left FIFA
needing to exclude one of the three (qualified) nations who were eliminated in
the 1986 quarter-finals: Brazil, England or Spain.

Owing to their performance in 1982 but also to their overall World Cup record,
Brazil were seeded third and not considered to drop out of the seedings. FIFA
opted to seed England ahead of Spain. Spain had only been eliminated in 1986
on penalties, albeit by fourth-placed Belgium, while England had been defeated
in 90 minutes by eventual winners Argentina; both countries had also reached
the second stage in the 1982 event, playing in the same group in the second
group stage with England ending up ahead of Spain, but Spain had also appeared
in the [1978 event](/wiki/1978_FIFA_World_Cup "1978 FIFA World Cup"), while
England had failed to qualify. FIFA President [João
Havelange](/wiki/Jo%C3%A3o_Havelange "João Havelange") had reportedly earlier
stated that Spain would be seeded.

Spanish officials believed the seeding was contrived to ensure England would
be placed in Group F, the group to be held off the Italian mainland, in a bid
to contain England's hooliganism problems. Their coach [Luis
Suárez](/wiki/Luis_Su%C3%A1rez_Miramontes "Luis Suárez Miramontes") said, "We
feel we've been cheated...they wanted to seed England and to send it to
Cagliari at all costs. So they invented this formula".[20] FIFA countered that
"the formula was based on the teams' respective showings during the previous
two World Cups. England merited the sixth position. This is in no way a
concession to English hooliganism".[20]

Meanwhile, the Netherlands also had an argument that on grounds of recent
footballing form, they should be seeded, as the winners of the [1988 European
Championship](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_1988 "UEFA Euro 1988"), in which both Spain and
England had been eliminated in the group stages, while Belgium (fourth in the
1986 World Cup after beating Spain, and thus seeded in 1990) had failed to
even qualify: but this argument was countered by the fact that the Netherlands
had themselves failed to qualify for both the 1982 and 1986 World Cups, which
was considered the most important factor in the decision not to seed them.[21]

As it happened, the two teams considered the most unlucky not to be seeded,
namely Spain and the Netherlands, were both drawn in groups against the two
teams considered the weakest of the seeded nations, namely Belgium and
England: and the arguments over the seeding positions fizzled out. England
could be said to have justified their seeded position by narrowly winning
their group ahead of the Netherlands: while Spain seemed to have made their
own point about being worth a seeded position, by defeating Belgium to top
their own group, in doing so gaining a measure of revenge for the fact that it
was Belgium who had eliminated them in 1986.

### Final
draw[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1990_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Final draw")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Mascotte_di_italia_90.JPG/220px-
Mascotte_di_italia_90.JPG)](/wiki/File:Mascotte_di_italia_90.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Mascotte_di_italia_90.JPG "Enlarge")

_Ciao_ , a [stick figure](/wiki/Stick_figure "Stick figure") in the colours of
the [Italy _Tricolore_](/wiki/Flag_of_Italy "Flag of Italy"), was the
[mascot](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_mascots "FIFA World Cup mascots") for the 1990
FIFA World Cup.

On 9 December 1989 the draw was conducted at the [Palazzetto dello
Sport](/wiki/Palazzetto_dello_Sport "Palazzetto dello Sport") in Rome, where
the teams were drawn out from the three pots to be placed with the seeded
teams in their predetermined groups. The only stipulation of the draw was that
no group could feature two South American teams.[22] The ceremony was hosted
by Italian television presenter [Pippo Baudo](/wiki/Pippo_Baudo "Pippo
Baudo"), with Italian actress [Sophia Loren](/wiki/Sophia_Loren "Sophia
Loren") and opera singer [Luciano Pavarotti](/wiki/Luciano_Pavarotti "Luciano
Pavarotti") conducting the draw alongside FIFA general secretary [Sepp
Blatter](/wiki/Sepp_Blatter "Sepp Blatter").[23]

The draw show was FIFA's most ambitious yet with [Pelé](/wiki/Pel%C3%A9
"Pelé"), [Bobby Moore](/wiki/Bobby_Moore "Bobby Moore") and [Karl-Heinz
Rummenigge](/wiki/Karl-Heinz_Rummenigge "Karl-Heinz Rummenigge") appearing, as
well as a performance of the Italian version of the [tournament's official
song](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_official_songs "FIFA World Cup official songs") "To
Be Number One" by Giorgio Moroder, performed as "[Un'estate
italiana](/wiki/Un%27estate_italiana "Un'estate italiana")" by [Edoardo
Bennato](/wiki/Edoardo_Bennato "Edoardo Bennato") and [Gianna
Nannini](/wiki/Gianna_Nannini "Gianna Nannini").[24]

The event also featured the [official mascot](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_mascots
"FIFA World Cup mascots") of this World Cup, _Ciao_ , a [stick
figure](/wiki/Stick_figure "Stick figure") player with a football head and an
[Italian tricolor body](/wiki/Flag_of_Italy "Flag of Italy") that formed the
word "ITALIA" when deconstructed and reconstructed.[25] Its name is a greeting
in Italian.

## Tournament
review[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1990_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Tournament review")]

The finals tournament began in Italy on 8 June and concluded on 8 July. The
format of the 1990 competition remained the same as in
[1986](/wiki/1986_FIFA_World_Cup "1986 FIFA World Cup"): 24 qualified teams
were divided into six groups of four. The top two teams and four best third-
place finishers from the six groups advanced to the knockout stage, which
eliminated the teams until a winner emerged. In total, 52 games were played.

### Negative
tactics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1990_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Negative tactics")]

The tournament generated a record low goals-per-game average and a then-record
of 16 red cards were handed out.[5] In the knockout stage, many teams played
defensively for 120 minutes, with the intention of trying their luck in the
penalty shoot-out, rather than risk going forward. Two exceptions were the
eventual champions West Germany and hosts Italy, the only teams to win three
of their four knockout matches in normal time. There were four penalty shoot-
outs, a record subsequently equalled in the [2006](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup
"2006 FIFA World Cup"), [2014](/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup "2014 FIFA World
Cup") and [2018](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup "2018 FIFA World Cup") tournaments.
Eight matches went to extra time, a record equalled in the [2014
tournament](/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup "2014 FIFA World Cup").

Ireland and Argentina were prime examples of this trend of cautious defensive
play; the Irish team fell behind in two of their three group matches and only
equalised late in both games. Losing finalists Argentina, meanwhile, scored
only five goals in the entire tournament (a record low for a finalist).
Argentina also became the first team to advance twice on penalty shoot-outs
and the first team to fail to score and have a player sent off in a World Cup
final.[1]

Largely as a result of this trend FIFA introduced the [back-pass
rule](/wiki/Back-pass_rule "Back-pass rule") in time for the [1994
tournament](/wiki/1994_FIFA_World_Cup "1994 FIFA World Cup") to make it harder
for teams to time-waste by repeatedly passing the ball back for their
goalkeepers to pick up. [Three, rather than two
points](/wiki/Three_points_for_a_win "Three points for a win") would be
awarded for victories at future tournaments to help further encourage
attacking play.

### Emergence of
Cameroon[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1990_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Emergence of Cameroon")]

[Cameroon](/wiki/Cameroon_national_football_team "Cameroon national football
team") reached the quarter-finals, where they were narrowly defeated by
England.[1] They opened the tournament with a shock victory over reigning
champions Argentina, before topping the group ahead of them,
[Romania](/wiki/Romania_national_football_team "Romania national football
team") and [European Championship](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_1988 "UEFA Euro 1988")
runners-up the [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union_national_football_team
"Soviet Union national football team"). Their success was fired by the goals
of [Roger Milla](/wiki/Roger_Milla "Roger Milla"), a 38-year-old forward who
came out of international retirement to join the national squad at the last
moment after a personal request from Cameroonian President [Paul
Biya](/wiki/Paul_Biya "Paul Biya"). Milla's four goals and flamboyant goal
celebrations made him one of the tournament's biggest stars as well as taking
Cameroon to the last eight.[1] Most of Cameroon's squad was made up of players
who played in France's premier football league, [Ligue 1](/wiki/Ligue_1 "Ligue
1")\- French is one of the officially spoken languages in Cameroon, it being a
former French territory. In reaching this stage, they had gone further than
any African nation had ever managed in a World Cup before; a feat only
equalled twice since (by [Senegal](/wiki/Senegal_national_football_team
"Senegal national football team") in [2002](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup "2002
FIFA World Cup") and [Ghana](/wiki/Ghana_national_football_team "Ghana
national football team") in [2010](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup "2010 FIFA World
Cup")). Their success was African football's biggest yet on the world stage
and FIFA subsequently decided to allocate the [CAF qualifying
zone](/wiki/Confederation_of_African_Football "Confederation of African
Football") an additional place for the next World Cup tournament.

### All-champion final
four[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1990_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: All-champion final four")]

Despite the performances of nations such as Cameroon, Colombia, Ireland,
Romania and Costa Rica, the semi-finalists consisted of Argentina, England,
Italy and West Germany, all previous World Cup winners, with eight previous
titles between them. After the [1970 tournament](/wiki/1970_FIFA_World_Cup
"1970 FIFA World Cup"), this is only the second time in the history of the
World Cup this has occurred. The teams which finished first, second and third
had also contested both the two previous World Cup Finals between themselves.

"Edit section: Results")]

### Group
stage[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1990_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Group stage")]

_All times are[Central European Summer
Time](/wiki/Central_European_Summer_Time "Central European Summer Time")
([UTC+2](/wiki/UTC%2B02:00 "UTC+02:00"))_

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/1990_world_cup.png/600px-1990_world_cup.png)](/wiki/File:1990_world_cup.png)

[](/wiki/File:1990_world_cup.png "Enlarge")

Champion Runner-up |  Third place Fourth place |  Quarter-finals Round of 16 |  Group stage  
---|---|---|---  
  
In the following tables:

  * **Pld** = total games played
  * **W** = total games won
  * **D** = total games drawn (tied)
  * **L** = total games lost
  * **GF** = total goals scored (goals for)
  * **GA** = total goals conceded (goals against)
  * **GD** = goal difference (GF−GA)
  * **Pts** = total points accumulated

The Group stage saw the twenty-four teams divided into six groups of four
teams. Each group was a [round-robin](/wiki/Round-robin_tournament "Round-
robin tournament") of six games, where each team played one match against each
of the other teams in the same group. Teams were awarded two points for a win,
one point for a draw and none for a defeat. The teams coming first and second
in each group qualified for the Round of 16. The four best third-placed teams
would also advance to the next stage.

Typical of a World Cup staged in Europe, the matches all started at either
5:00 or 9:00 in the evening; this allowed for the games to avoid being played
in the heat of an Italian summer, which would soar past 86F (30C) all over
Italy.

If teams were level on points, they were ranked on the following criteria in
order:

>   1. Greatest total goal difference in the three group matches
>   2. Greatest number of goals scored in the three group matches
>   3. If teams remained level after those criteria, a mini-group would be
> formed from those teams, who would be ranked on:
>     1. Most points earned in matches against other teams in the tie
>     2. Greatest goal difference in matches against other teams in the tie
>     3. Greatest number of goals scored in matches against other teams in the
> tie
>   4. If teams remained level after all these criteria, FIFA would hold a
> drawing of lots
>

#### Group
A[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1990_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=16 "Edit
section: Group A")]

Main article: [1990 FIFA World Cup Group A](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_A
"1990 FIFA World Cup Group A")

Hosts [Italy](/wiki/Italy_national_football_team "Italy national football
team") won Group A with a 100 percent record. They beat
[Austria](/wiki/Austria_national_football_team "Austria national football
team") 1–0 thanks to substitute [Salvatore 'Totò'
Schillaci](/wiki/Salvatore_Schillaci "Salvatore Schillaci"), who had played
only one international before but would become a star during the tournament. A
second 1–0 victory followed against a [United States
team](/wiki/United_States_men%27s_national_soccer_team "United States men's
national soccer team") already thumped 5–1 by
[Czechoslovakia](/wiki/Czechoslovakia_national_football_team "Czechoslovakia
national football team"). The Czechoslovaks ended runners-up in the group,
while the USA's first appearance in a World Cup Finals since
[1950](/wiki/1950_FIFA_World_Cup "1950 FIFA World Cup") ended with three
consecutive defeats.

#### Group
B[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1990_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=17 "Edit
section: Group B")]

Main article: [1990 FIFA World Cup Group B](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_B
"1990 FIFA World Cup Group B")

[Cameroon](/wiki/Cameroon_national_football_team "Cameroon national football
team") defeated reigning champions
[Argentina](/wiki/Argentina_national_football_team "Argentina national
football team"). Despite ending the match with only nine men, the African team
held on for a shock 1–0 win, with contrasting fortunes for the brothers Biyik:
François Omam scoring the winning goal, shortly after seeing Andre Kana sent
off for a serious foul. In their second game the introduction of [Roger
Milla](/wiki/Roger_Milla "Roger Milla") was the catalyst for a 2–1 win over
[Romania](/wiki/Romania_national_football_team "Romania national football
team"), Milla scoring twice from the bench (making him the oldest goalscorer
in the tournament). With progression assured, Cameroon slumped to a 4–0 defeat
in their final group game to the [Soviet
Union](/wiki/USSR_national_football_team "USSR national football team") (in
what would be their last World Cup due to the [dissolution of the Soviet
Union](/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union "Dissolution of the Soviet
Union")), who were striving to stay in the tournament on goal difference after
successive 2–0 defeats. Argentina lost their veteran goalkeeper, Nery Pumpido,
to a broken leg during their victory over the USSR: his replacement, Sergio
Goycochea, proved to be one of the stars of their tournament. In the final
match, a 1–1 draw between Romania and Argentina sent both through, equal on
points and on goal difference but Romania having the advantage on goals
scored: Romania were thus second, Argentina qualified as one of the best
third-placed teams.

#### Group
C[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1990_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=18 "Edit
section: Group C")]

Main article: [1990 FIFA World Cup Group C](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_C
"1990 FIFA World Cup Group C")

[Costa Rica](/wiki/Costa_Rica_national_football_team "Costa Rica national
football team") beat [Scotland](/wiki/Scotland_national_football_team
"Scotland national football team") 1–0 in their first match, lost 1–0 to
[Brazil](/wiki/Brazil_national_football_team "Brazil national football team")
in their second, then saw off [Sweden](/wiki/Sweden_national_football_team
"Sweden national football team") 2–1 to claim a place in the second round.
Brazil took maximum points from the group. They began with a 2–1 win over
Sweden, then beat both Costa Rica and Scotland 1–0. Scotland's 2–1 win over
Sweden was not enough to save them from an early return home as one of the two
lowest-ranked third-placed teams.

#### Group
D[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1990_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=19 "Edit
section: Group D")]

Main article: [1990 FIFA World Cup Group D](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_D
"1990 FIFA World Cup Group D")

Group D featured the most goals of all the groups, most due to two large wins
of [West Germany](/wiki/Germany_national_football_team "Germany national
football team") and defensive inadequacies of a [United Arab
Emirates](/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates_national_football_team "United Arab
Emirates national football team") team that lost 2–0 to
[Colombia](/wiki/Colombia_national_football_team "Colombia national football
team"), 5–1 to West Germany and 4–1 to
[Yugoslavia](/wiki/Yugoslavia_national_football_team "Yugoslavia national
football team"). The West Germans topped the group after a 4–1 opening victory
over group runners-up Yugoslavia.

#### Group
E[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1990_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=20 "Edit
section: Group E")]

Main article: [1990 FIFA World Cup Group E](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_E
"1990 FIFA World Cup Group E")

The winners of Group E were [Spain](/wiki/Spain_national_football_team "Spain
national football team"), for whom [Michel](/wiki/Michel_\(footballer\)
"Michel \(footballer\)") hit a [hat-trick](/wiki/List_of_FIFA_World_Cup_hat-
tricks "List of FIFA World Cup hat-tricks") as they beat [South
Korea](/wiki/South_Korea_national_football_team "South Korea national football
team") 3–1 in an unbeaten group campaign.
[Belgium](/wiki/Belgium_national_football_team "Belgium national football
team") won their first two games against South Korea and
[Uruguay](/wiki/Uruguay_national_football_team "Uruguay national football
team") to ensure their progress; Uruguay's advance to the second round came
with an injury time winner against South Korea to edge them through as the
weakest of the third-placed sides to remain in the tournament.

#### Group
F[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1990_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=21 "Edit
section: Group F")]

Main article: [1990 FIFA World Cup Group F](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_F
"1990 FIFA World Cup Group F")

Group F, featured the [Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands_national_football_team
"Netherlands national football team"),
[England](/wiki/England_national_football_team "England national football
team"), the [Republic of
Ireland](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland_national_football_team "Republic of Ireland
national football team") and [Egypt](/wiki/Egypt_national_football_team "Egypt
national football team"). In the six group games, no team managed to score
more than once in a match. England beat Egypt 1–0, the only match with a
decisive result, and that was enough to win the group. The group containing
England, Ireland and the Netherlands was remarkably similar to the group stage
of the 1988 European Championship, which had eventually been won by the
Netherlands, with England crashing out with three losses (to Ireland, the
Netherlands and the USSR) and Ireland also narrowly failing to progress after
losing to the Netherlands and drawing with the USSR. The results of the 1990
group, however, were different: England took the lead with an early goal for
Lineker against Ireland, but Sheedy's late equalizer gave them a share of the
spoils. The Netherlands failed to replicate their form of two years earlier,
only drawing against Egypt: they had taken a 1-0 lead, but without impressing,
and Egypt were well worth their equalizer courtesy of a penalty by Abdelghani.
England then had much the better of their goalless draw with the Netherlands:
indeed they had the ball in the net once, from a free-kick by Pearce, but it
was disallowed. For the second World Cup in succession, however, England lost
their captain Bryan Robson to an injury which put him out of the tournament,
just over halfway through their second match. Ireland and Egypt barely
registered a shot on goal between them in the other 0-0 draw: after the first
four matches all four teams had equal records with 2 draws, 1 goal for and 1
goal against. England's victory over Egypt, thanks to a 58th-minute goal from
[Mark Wright](/wiki/Mark_Wright_\(footballer_born_1963\) "Mark Wright
\(footballer born 1963\)"), put them top of the group: in the other match,
Gullit gave the Netherlands the lead against Ireland, but Niall Quinn scored a
second-half equalizer and the two teams finished in second and third, still
with identical records. Both teams qualified but they had to draw lots to
place the teams in second and third place.

Ireland won the drawing of lots against the Netherlands for second place in
Group F: the Netherlands were the only third-placed team not to have won any
matches - or lost any: they progressed with three draws (3 points), ahead of
Austria and Scotland who each had one win and two losses (2 points).

### Knockout
stage[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1990_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: Knockout stage")]

Main article: [1990 FIFA World Cup knockout
stage](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage "1990 FIFA World Cup knockout
stage")

The [knockout stage](/wiki/Single-elimination_tournament "Single-elimination
tournament") involved the 16 teams that qualified from the group stage of the
tournament. There were four rounds of matches, with each round eliminating
half of the teams entering that round. The successive rounds were: round of
16, quarter-finals, semi-finals, final. There was also a play-off to decide
third/fourth place. For each game in the knockout stage, any draw at 90
minutes was followed by 30 minutes of [extra
time](/wiki/Overtime_\(association_football\) "Overtime \(association
football\)"); if scores were still level there would be a [penalty shoot-
out](/wiki/Penalty_shoot-out_\(association_football\) "Penalty shoot-out
\(association football\)") (five penalties each, if neither team already had a
decisive advantage, and more if necessary) to determine who progressed to the
next round. Scores after extra time are indicated by (aet) and penalty shoot-
outs are indicated by (p).

#### Round of
16[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1990_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=24 "Edit
section: Round of 16")]

Two of the ties – Brazil vs Argentina and Italy vs Uruguay – pitted former
champion countries against each other and West Germany met the Netherlands in
a rematch of the [1974 World Cup Final](/wiki/1974_FIFA_World_Cup_Final "1974
FIFA World Cup Final").

The all-South American game was won for Argentina by a goal from [Claudio
Caniggia](/wiki/Claudio_Caniggia "Claudio Caniggia") with 10 minutes remaining
after a run through the Brazilian defence by [Diego
Maradona](/wiki/Diego_Maradona "Diego Maradona") and an outstanding
performance from their goalkeeper [Sergio Goycochea](/wiki/Sergio_Goycochea
"Sergio Goycochea"). It would later come to light that
[Branco](/wiki/Branco_\(footballer\) "Branco \(footballer\)") had been offered
water spiked with tranquillisers by Maradona and [Ricardo
Giusti](/wiki/Ricardo_Giusti "Ricardo Giusti") during half time, to slow him
down in the second half. Initially discredited by the press, Branco would be
publicly proven right years later, when Maradona confessed the episode on a TV
show in Argentina.[26] As for Italy, a strong second half showing saw the
hosts beat Uruguay 2–0, thanks to another goal from Schillaci and one from
[Aldo Serena](/wiki/Aldo_Serena "Aldo Serena").

The match between West Germany and the Netherlands was held in Milan, and both
sides featured several notable players from the two Milanese clubs (Germans
[Andreas Brehme](/wiki/Andreas_Brehme "Andreas Brehme"), [Lothar
Matthäus](/wiki/Lothar_Matth%C3%A4us "Lothar Matthäus") and [Jürgen
Klinsmann](/wiki/J%C3%BCrgen_Klinsmann "Jürgen Klinsmann") for
[Internazionale](/wiki/F.C._Internazionale_Milano "F.C. Internazionale
Milano"), and Dutchmen [Marco van Basten](/wiki/Marco_van_Basten "Marco van
Basten"), [Ruud Gullit](/wiki/Ruud_Gullit "Ruud Gullit") and [Frank
Rijkaard](/wiki/Frank_Rijkaard "Frank Rijkaard") for [Milan](/wiki/A.C._Milan
"A.C. Milan")). After 22 minutes [Rudi Völler](/wiki/Rudi_V%C3%B6ller "Rudi
Völler") and Rijkaard were both dismissed after a number of incidents between
the two players (including Rijkaard spitting on Völler) left the Argentine
referee with no option but to send them both off. As the players walked off
the pitch together, Rijkaard spat on Völler a second time. Early in the second
half, [Jürgen Klinsmann](/wiki/J%C3%BCrgen_Klinsmann "Jürgen Klinsmann") put
the West Germans ahead and [Andreas Brehme](/wiki/Andreas_Brehme "Andreas
Brehme") added a second with eight minutes left. A [Ronald
Koeman](/wiki/Ronald_Koeman "Ronald Koeman") penalty for the Netherlands in
the 89th minute narrowed the score to 2–1 but the Germans saw the game out to
gain some revenge for their [exit to the Dutch in the previous European
Championship](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_1988#Semi-finals "UEFA Euro 1988").

Meanwhile, the heroics of Cameroon and Roger Milla continued in their game
with Colombia. Milla was introduced as a second-half substitute with the game
goalless, eventually breaking the deadlock midway in extra time. Three minutes
later he netted a second after Colombian goalkeeper, [René
Higuita](/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Higuita "René Higuita") was dispossessed by Milla
while well out of his goal, leaving the striker free to slot the ball into the
empty net. Though the deficit was soon reduced to 2–1, Cameroon held on to
become the first African team ever to reach the World Cup quarter-finals.
Costa Rica were comfortably beaten 4–1 by Czechoslovakia, for whom [Tomáš
Skuhravý](/wiki/Tom%C3%A1%C5%A1_Skuhrav%C3%BD "Tomáš Skuhravý") scored the
tournament's second and final [hat-trick](/wiki/Hat-trick "Hat-trick").

The Republic of Ireland's match with Romania remained goalless after extra
time and the Irish side won 5–4 on penalties. [David
O'Leary](/wiki/David_O%27Leary "David O'Leary") converted the penalty that
clinched Ireland's place in the quarter-finals. Ireland thus became the first
team since Sweden in [1938](/wiki/1938_FIFA_World_Cup "1938 FIFA World Cup")
to reach the last eight in a World Cup finals tournament without winning a
match outright. Yugoslavia beat Spain 2–1 after extra time, with [Dragan
Stojković](/wiki/Dragan_Stojkovi%C4%87 "Dragan Stojković") scoring both the
Yugoslavs' goals. England were the final qualifier against Belgium, as
midfielder [David Platt](/wiki/David_Platt_\(footballer\) "David Platt
\(footballer\)")'s swivelling volley broke the stalemate with the game moments
away from a penalty shoot-out.

#### Quarter-
finals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1990_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=25
"Edit section: Quarter-finals")]

The first game of the last 8 saw Argentina and a Yugoslav side, reduced to 10
men after only half an hour, play out a goalless stalemate. The holders
reached the semi-finals after winning the penalty shoot-out 3–2, despite
Maradona having his penalty saved. A second Argentine miss (by [Pedro
Troglio](/wiki/Pedro_Troglio "Pedro Troglio")) looked to have eliminated them
until goalkeeper [Sergio Goycochea](/wiki/Sergio_Goycochea "Sergio Goycochea")
– playing because first choice [Nery Pumpido](/wiki/Nery_Pumpido "Nery
Pumpido") broke his leg during the group stage – rescued his side by stopping
the Yugoslavs' final two spotkicks.

The Republic of Ireland's World Cup run was brought to an end by a single goal
from Schillaci in the first half of their quarter-final with hosts Italy. West
Germany beat Czechoslovakia with a 25th minute [Lothar
Matthäus](/wiki/Lothar_Matth%C3%A4us "Lothar Matthäus") penalty.

The quarter-final between England and Cameroon was the only quarter-final to
produce more than one goal. Despite Cameroon's heroics earlier in the
tournament, [David Platt](/wiki/David_Platt_\(footballer\) "David Platt
\(footballer\)") put England ahead in the 25th minute. At half-time, Milla was
brought on. In the second half, the game was turned on its head during a five-
minute stretch: first Cameroon were awarded a penalty from which [Emmanuel
Kunde](/wiki/Emmanuel_Kunde "Emmanuel Kunde") scored the equaliser; then in
the 65th minute [Eugene Ekeke](/wiki/Eugene_Ekeke "Eugene Ekeke") put Cameroon
ahead. Cameroon came within eight minutes of reaching the semi-finals before
they conceded a penalty, which Gary Lineker converted. Midway through extra
time, England were awarded another penalty and Lineker again scored from the
spot. England were through to the semi-finals for the first time since the
days of [Bobby Moore](/wiki/Bobby_Moore "Bobby Moore") 24 years prior.

#### Semi-
finals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1990_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=26
"Edit section: Semi-finals")]

The first semi-final featured the host nation, Italy, and the world champions,
Argentina in Naples. 'Toto' Schillaci scored yet again to put Italy ahead in
the 17th minute, but Claudio Caniggia equalised midway through the second
half, breaking [Walter Zenga](/wiki/Walter_Zenga "Walter Zenga")'s clean sheet
streak throughout the tournament. There were no more goals in the 90 minutes
or in extra time despite Maradona (who played for Naples in Serie A at the
time) showing glimpses of magic, but there was a sending-off: [Ricardo
Giusti](/wiki/Ricardo_Giusti "Ricardo Giusti") of Argentina was shown the red
card in the 13th minute of extra time. Argentina went through on penalties,
winning the shoot-out 4–3 after more heroics from Goycochea.

The semi-final between West Germany and England at
[Juventus](/wiki/Juventus_F.C. "Juventus F.C.")'s home stadium in Turin was
goalless at half-time. Then, in the 60th minute, a shot from Andreas Brehme
was deflected by [Paul Parker](/wiki/Paul_Parker_\(footballer\) "Paul Parker
\(footballer\)") into his own net. England equalised with ten minutes left;
Gary Lineker was the scorer. The game ended 1–1. Extra time yielded more
chances. Klinsmann was guilty of two glaring misses and both sides struck a
post. England had another Platt goal disallowed for offside. The match went to
penalties, and West Germany went on to win the shoot-out 4–3.[27]

#### Third-place play-
off[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1990_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=27 "Edit
section: Third-place play-off")]

The game saw three goals in a 15-minute spell. [Roberto
Baggio](/wiki/Roberto_Baggio "Roberto Baggio") opened the scoring after a rare
mistake by England's goalkeeper Peter Shilton, in his final game before
international retirement, presented a simple opportunity. A header by [David
Platt](/wiki/David_Platt_\(footballer\) "David Platt \(footballer\)") levelled
the game 10 minutes later but [Schillaci](/wiki/Salvatore_Schillaci "Salvatore
Schillaci") was fouled in the penalty area five minutes later, leading to a
penalty. Schillaci himself got up to convert the kick to win him the
tournament's [Golden Boot](/wiki/World_Cup_Golden_Boot "World Cup Golden
Boot") for his six-goal tally. [Nicola Berti](/wiki/Nicola_Berti "Nicola
Berti") had a goal ruled out minutes later, but the hosts claimed third place.
England had the consolation prize of the Fair Play award, having received no
red cards and the lowest average number of yellows per match.

####
Final[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1990_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=28
"Edit section: Final")]

Main article: [1990 FIFA World Cup Final](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_Final
"1990 FIFA World Cup Final")

The final between West Germany and Argentina has been cited as the most
cynical and lowest-quality of all World Cup Finals.[1][2][28][29][30] In the
65th minute, Argentina's [Pedro Monzon](/wiki/Pedro_Monzon "Pedro Monzon") \-
himself only recently on as a substitute - was sent off for a foul on [Jürgen
Klinsmann](/wiki/J%C3%BCrgen_Klinsmann "Jürgen Klinsmann"). Monzon was the
first player ever to be sent off in a World Cup Final.

Argentina, weakened by suspension and injury, offered little attacking threat
throughout a contest dominated by the West Germans, who struggled to create
many clear goalscoring opportunities. The only goal of the contest arrived in
the 85th minute when Mexican referee [Edgardo Codesal](/wiki/Edgardo_Codesal
"Edgardo Codesal") awarded a
[penalty](/wiki/Penalty_kick_\(association_football\) "Penalty kick
\(association football\)") to West Germany, after a foul on [Rudi
Völler](/wiki/Rudi_V%C3%B6ller "Rudi Völler") by [Roberto
Sensini](/wiki/Roberto_Sensini "Roberto Sensini") leading to Argentinian
protests.[31] [Andreas Brehme](/wiki/Andreas_Brehme "Andreas Brehme")
converted the spot kick to settle the contest. In the closing moments,
Argentina were reduced to nine after [Gustavo Dezotti](/wiki/Gustavo_Dezotti
"Gustavo Dezotti"), who had already been yellow carded earlier in the match,
received a red card when he hauled [Jürgen Kohler](/wiki/J%C3%BCrgen_Kohler
"Jürgen Kohler") to the ground during a stoppage in play. The 1–0 scoreline
provided another first: Argentina were the first team to fail to score in a
World Cup Final.

With its third title (and three second-place finishes) West Germany – in its
final tournament before [national reunification](/wiki/German_reunification
"German reunification") – became the most successful World Cup nation at the
time. West German manager [Franz Beckenbauer](/wiki/Franz_Beckenbauer "Franz
Beckenbauer") became the only man to both captain (in
[1974](/wiki/1974_FIFA_World_Cup "1974 FIFA World Cup")) and manage a World
Cup winning team, and only the second man (after [Mário
Zagallo](/wiki/M%C3%A1rio_Zagallo "Mário Zagallo") of Brazil) to win the World
Cup as a player and as team manager. It was also the first time a team from
UEFA won the final against a non-European team.

##
Goalscorers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1990_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=29
"Edit section: Goalscorers")]

[Salvatore Schillaci](/wiki/Salvatore_Schillaci "Salvatore Schillaci")
received the [Golden Boot](/wiki/World_Cup_Golden_Boot "World Cup Golden
Boot") award for scoring six goals in the World Cup. This made him the second
Italian footballer to have this honour, after [Paolo Rossi](/wiki/Paolo_Rossi
"Paolo Rossi") won the award in [1982](/wiki/1982_FIFA_World_Cup#Scorers "1982
FIFA World Cup"). In total, 115 goals were scored by 75 players (none credited
as [own goals](/wiki/Own_goal_\(association_football\) "Own goal \(association
football\)")).

##
Statistics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1990_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=33
"Edit section: Statistics")]

  * Most wins: **[Italy](/wiki/Italy_national_football_team "Italy national football team")** (6)
  * Most defeats: **[South Korea](/wiki/South_Korea_national_football_team "South Korea national football team"), [Sweden](/wiki/Sweden_national_football_team "Sweden national football team"), [UAE](/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates_national_football_team "United Arab Emirates national football team"), [United States](/wiki/United_States_men%27s_national_soccer_team "United States men's national soccer team")** (3)
  * First goal: **[François Omam Biyik](/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Omam_Biyik "François Omam Biyik")** (for [Cameroon vs Argentina](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_B#Argentina_vs_Cameroon "1990 FIFA World Cup Group B"); Group B, 8 June)
  * Fastest goal in a match: **3 minutes 59 seconds** – [Safet Sušić](/wiki/Safet_Su%C5%A1i%C4%87 "Safet Sušić") (for [Yugoslavia vs UAE](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_D#Yugoslavia_vs_UAE "1990 FIFA World Cup Group D"); Group D, 19 June)
  * Latest goal scored in a match (apart from penalty shoot-outs): **119 minutes** – [David Platt](/wiki/David_Platt_\(footballer\) "David Platt \(footballer\)") (for [England vs Belgium](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage#England_vs_Belgium "1990 FIFA World Cup knockout stage"); Round of 16, 26 June)
  * Biggest win: **5–1** – by [Czechoslovakia vs United States](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_A#United_States_vs_Czechoslovakia "1990 FIFA World Cup Group A"), and by [West Germany vs UAE](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_D#West_Germany_vs_UAE "1990 FIFA World Cup Group D")
  * Most goals in the tournament (team): **[West Germany](/wiki/Germany_national_football_team "Germany national football team")** (15)
  * Most goals in the tournament (player): **[Salvatore Schillaci](/wiki/Salvatore_Schillaci "Salvatore Schillaci")** ([Italy](/wiki/Italy_national_football_team "Italy national football team")) (6)
  * Fewest goals in the tournament (team): **[Egypt](/wiki/Egypt_national_football_team "Egypt national football team")** and **[South Korea](/wiki/South_Korea_national_football_team "South Korea national football team")** (1)
  * Most goals in a game: **6** ([United States 1 Czechoslovakia 5](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_A#United_States_vs_Czechoslovakia "1990 FIFA World Cup Group A"); [West Germany 5 UAE 1](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_D#West_Germany_vs_UAE "1990 FIFA World Cup Group D"))
  * Most goals in a game (player): **3** , by **[Míchel](/wiki/M%C3%ADchel_\(footballer\) "Míchel \(footballer\)")** (for [Spain vs South Korea](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_E#South_Korea_vs_Spain "1990 FIFA World Cup Group E")) and **[Tomáš Skuhravý](/wiki/Tom%C3%A1%C5%A1_Skuhrav%C3%BD "Tomáš Skuhravý")** (for [Czechoslovakia vs Costa Rica](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage#Czechoslovakia_vs_Costa_Rica "1990 FIFA World Cup knockout stage"))
  * Fewest goals conceded: **[Brazil](/wiki/Brazil_national_football_team "Brazil national football team")** , **[Egypt](/wiki/Egypt_national_football_team "Egypt national football team")** and **[Italy](/wiki/Italy_national_football_team "Italy national football team")** (2)
  * Total goals scored: **115** (average 2.21 goals per game, a record low in World Cup history)
  * Most clean sheets: **[Italy](/wiki/Italy_national_football_team "Italy national football team")** (5)
  * Total penalties awarded: **18** (13 scored, 5 missed)[35]
  * Most yellow cards in a game: **9** – **[Austria vs United States](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_A#Austria_vs_United_States "1990 FIFA World Cup Group A")** (Group A, 19 June)
  * Most yellow cards in the tournament: **[Argentina](/wiki/Argentina_national_football_team "Argentina national football team")** (22)
  * Total yellow cards: **162**[36]
  * Most red cards in the tournament: **[Argentina](/wiki/Argentina_national_football_team "Argentina national football team")** (3)
  * Total red cards: **16** (a record high for a 24 team World Cup)
  * Highest attendance: **74,765** – **[West Germany vs Yugoslavia](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_D#West_Germany_vs_Yugoslavia "1990 FIFA World Cup Group D")** (Group D, 10 June)
  * Lowest attendance: **27,833** – **[Yugoslavia vs UAE](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_D#Yugoslavia_vs_UAE "1990 FIFA World Cup Group D")** (Group D, 19 June)
  * Average attendance: **48,391** (5th highest in World Cup history)
  * Oldest player: **[Peter Shilton](/wiki/Peter_Shilton "Peter Shilton")** ([England](/wiki/England_national_football_team "England national football team")) (40 years 292 days)
  * Youngest player: **[Rónald González Brenes](/wiki/R%C3%B3nald_Gonz%C3%A1lez_Brenes "Rónald González Brenes")** ([Costa Rica](/wiki/Costa_Rica_national_football_team "Costa Rica national football team")) (19 years 307 days)
  * Italy's performance of 6 wins, 1 draw and 0 losses is the highest ever winning percentage for a team that did not win the World Cup.[37]
  * The Republic of Ireland became the second team in World Cup history to reach the last eight without winning a match (Sweden progressed to the last eight by default in 1938 when Austria withdrew).
